body.header: Look carefully at the flow chart and complete the report by choosing the word or phrase which best fits each gap.

section.p: One way in which new laws come into existence in Britain is through the parliamentary process. When a government wishes to bring new legislation into force, there are certain steps which must be followedfolloware followed.

FirstFirstlyAt first, the relevant government department consults with experts. Based on their advice, a first draft, known as a Bill, is writtenhad writtenwritten by parliamentary draftspeople. Provided thatIn caseUnless the government department is satisfied with the wording of the Bill, it can be introducedintroduceis introduced to the House of Commons. At the same timeLaterPrior to this, the Bill is made available to the public on the Internet. DuringThroughWhile this process, any amendments made to the Bill are also posted here. If the House of Commons votes for the Bill, it is thenafterbeforehand debated and amended by what is known as a standing committee. Any amendments are subsequentlybeforehandsimultaneously. reported to the House of Commons, which in turnafterotherwise votes for a second time. If the Bill passesis passedbe passed this stage, it is handed over to the House of Lords.

A similar process of amending and voting takes place in the House of Lords. The Lords can rejectrejectedbe rejected the Bill if they wish to, unlessin caseprovided that it is the second time it has passed through parliament. In this case, the Bill can be amendedis amendedamend but not rejected. FinallyIn the endAt the end, the Bill must be given the royal assent bytofrom the Queen. OnceNextSubsequently this formality has been dealt withhas dealt withhad been dealt with, the new law, now called an Act of Parliament, can come into force.

p.font: be followed: This is the correct answer.
follow: The passive is needed here.
are follow: After a modal verb such as 'must' we use the infinitive.
First: This is the correct answer.
Firstly: 'Firstly' is used when giving a list of reasons. It is more often used in discursive comparisons.
At first: 'At first' means 'in the beginning' and is usually used in stories and narrative comparisons.
is written: This is the correct answer.
had written/written: The passive form of the verb in the present tense is needed here.
be introduced: This is the correct answer.

section.p: The passive form is needed here.
After a modal such as 'can' the infinitive is needed.

p.font: At the same time: The Bill is made available on the Internet while the House of Commons is discussing it for the first time.
Later: Have another look at the flow chart. The Bill is made available on the Internet while the House of Common is discussing it for the first time.
Prior to: 'Prior to' means before. If you have another look at the flow chart, you'll see that this is not the case.
During: This is the correct answer.
Through: Perhaps you have confused 'through' with the word 'throughout'.
While: 'While' needs to be followed with a full verb clause. For example, 'While this process takes place…'
subsequently: This is the correct answer.
beforehand: Check the flow chart.
simultaneously: 'Simultaneously' means at the same time. Check the flow chart.
in turn: This means 'then'.
after: 'After' is a preposition and needs to be followed with a noun or 'ing' form.
otherwise: We use 'otherwise' to show what happens if a certain condition is not true.
passes: This is the correct answer.

section.p: This sentence is in active voice. You don't have to put all the verbs in passive.

p.font: reject: This sentence is in active voice. You don't have to put all the verbs in passive.
rejected: Present tenses are usually used to describe processes.
be rejected: This sentence is in active voice. You don't have to put all the verbs in passive.
Unless: This is the correct answer. 'Unless' means 'if not'.
In case: We use 'in case' to talk about precautions which ought to be taken. For example, 'Perhaps you ought to take an umbrella, in case it rains.' It doesn't have the same meaning as 'if'.
Provided that: 'Provided that' means 'if'. Here an expression or word is needed which means 'if not'. Check the flow chart again.
be amended: This is the correct answer.
is amended: After a modal such as 'can' the infinitive is needed.
amend: The passive form is needed here.
Finally: This is the correct answer.
In the end: We usually use this in narrative comparisons and stories, not reports describing a process.
At the end: This describes a place, not a point in a process. 'At the end of the road', for example.
by: This is the correct answer.
to/from: These are not the prepositions usually used to show the 'agent' of the passive verb.
Once: This is the correct answer.

section.p: A word which means 'when' is needed here.

p.font: has been dealt with: This is the correct answer.
has dealt with: This is not the correct form of the passive in present perfect. You have forgotten the auxiliary verb 'be'.
had been dealt with: This is past perfect in the passive. Here, the present perfect is needed.
